This, we are told, was the consideration that weighed with Otho's generals, when they proposed to draw the war into length, and, in particular, that Paulinus acted with that motive* He was the first and most distinguished of the consular rank, the highest in military reputation, and his conduct in Britain (a) had given jwiperior lustre to his name. But though it may be reasonable to admit, that a few, in that juncture, had the public good at heart, and wished to see two vile competitors, the most abandoned of mankind, post- poned to a virtuous prince; it is, notwith- standing, highly improbable that Paulinus, a man of experience and consummate un- derstanding, should, in an age so corrupt and profligate, amuse himself with hopes of finding one spark of virtue.
